) Purpose. This IRM provides procedural guidance and instructions for officers and group managers in SB/SE Field Collection to handle taxpayer resentation issues when working Collection cases. (
) Audience. The guidance located in this IRM is speciﬁcally intended for use revenue officers and group managers in SB/SE Field Collection as they are primary users of this IRM. (
) Policy Owner. Director, Collection Policy, SB/SE is the policy owner of this IRM. (
) Program Owner. Collection Policy, SB/SE is the program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders. Revenue officers and group managers in SB/SE Collection, Office of Professional Responsibility, TIGTA, and GLS are the primary stakeholders for this IRM. (

) Program Goals. When involved with Field Collection, taxpayers have a right retain representation. By following the procedures in this IRM, employees understand the authorities granted to the authorized representative, actions Internal Revenue Service (IRS) employees must take when a taxpayer has authorized representative, when and how to by-pass an authorized tive, and how to appropriately handle practitioner misconduct. (

GMs direct any questions or concerns to the appropriate Area contact for possible referral to Headquarters. (
) IRM

, Field Collecting Procedures, Taxpayer Representation, provides taxpayer representation procedural guidance to revenue officers and group managers in SB/SE Field Collection. This IRM provides guidance on the following topics: taxpayer representation, third party authorizations, changing cancelling a third party authorization, by-passing a taxpayer’s authorized sentative, and practitioner misconduct as these topics will arise while communicating with taxpayers and their authorized representatives. These cedures are consistent with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights and the Privacy Act

) Director, Collection Policy is responsible for the policies and procedures in IRM. (
) Director, Field Collection, has executive oversight for all Field Collection programs. (
) Field Collection area directors, territory managers, and group managers are responsible for ensuring compliance by Field Collection personnel with these procedures. (
) Revenue officers are responsible for reading and implementing the listed in this IRM. (

) Program Reviews: Operational reviews are conducted by the Collection area directors and territory managers annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to administrative and program requirements. Group managers participate in one or more Embedded Quality (EQ) consistency reviews each year to assist in rating EQ attributes. Group managers perform annual and periodic case and performance reviews as described in IRM

, Guide for Managers, Collection Group Manager, Territory Manager and Area Director Operational Aid. Collection Policy performs periodic program reviews to identify trends and opportunities for improvement. (

) Program Effectiveness: National Quality Reviews and consistency reviews routinely conducted to measure program consistency, effectiveness in case actions, and compliance with policy and procedures. Trends reported in reviews are used to promote and improve program effectiveness. Trends, ommendations, and corrective actions issued during the course of program and operational reviews are used to identify opportunities for improvement achieve program goals. (

, Resource Guide for Managers, tion Group Manager, Territory Manager and Area Director Operational Aid. (

) Awareness of taxpayer rights is vitally important. The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are re- sponsible for being familiar with and acting in accordance with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. The following taxpayer rights are in Publication
(rev.
), and are addressed in IRM
, Collection Appeal Rights, and throughout IRM Part
The right to be informed.
The right to quality service.
The right to pay no more than the correct amount of tax.
The right to challenge the IRS’s position and be heard.
The right to appeal an IRS decision in an independent forum.
The right to ﬁnality.
The right to privacy.
The right to conﬁdentiality.
The right to retain representation.
The right to a fair and just tax system. For additional information about TBOR, see
Representation
page (

) Every taxpayer is entitled to retain representation. Taxpayers may either represent themselves or, with proper written authorization, have someone represent them. A taxpayer’s representative must be an individual authorized practice before the IRS, such as an attorney, certiﬁed public accountant, or enrolled agent. Ordinarily, it is not required to research the status of a repre- sentative. However, you may choose to verify a representative’s eligibility. IRM
, Form
Factors to Consider, for research guidance. (

) Taxpayers have the right to be told that if they cannot afford to hire a tative, they may be eligible for assistance from a Low Income Taxpayer (LITC). You may refer a taxpayer to a LITC if you feel a taxpayer may be eligible for assistance. (

) A taxpayer may also authorize a third party to receive their conﬁdential tax formation. These designees may be individuals or entities and do not have be authorized to practice before the IRS. These designees do not represent the taxpayer in matters before the IRS. (

, Disclosure to and Practitioners, for additional guidance. (

) Records of all third party authorization documents are generally maintained the automated Centralized Authorization File (CAF). See IRM
, ceptions to Sending a Third Party Authorization to the CAF Function, for exceptions for sending a third party authorization to the CAF. (

) The CAF system consists of taxpayer records and representative records. a. Taxpayer records consist of modules for which the taxpayer has given third party authorization and cross–references to the records of the involved authorized representative(s) / designee(s). b. Representative records contain the name and address of the representative. c. Designee records contain the name and address of the designee. (

The Ethics and General Government Law Branch in the Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (General Legal Services) (EGG GLS) is responsible for rendering a legal advisory opinion on whether former employee is violating or has violated the post-employment laws. Note: When an IRS employee contacts GLS with an inquiry seeking legal advice about a possible post-employment violation, GLS’s role is that of a legal advisor. The employee is not considered to be making a report. (
) A post-employment violation may occur when a former IRS employee works on a speciﬁc matter in the private sector that they worked on or had official responsibility for while employed by the IRS. (
